to fit our needs
in a very opinionated way.

contents.title: Filter / Ignore
contents.description: YAML and JSON files are first class content payloads.

children.value: YAML and JSON files are first class content payloads.
But YAML and JSON files can also be

assets not related to content.
We may think this is not a trouble to let those files be consumed as content payloads.
But in some cases they may be big and will probably clutter the content engine.
We would like to define which YAML/JSON should be ignored by the content engine.
We would also like to define a filter for intermediate cases where we want to keep a small part of the JSON/YAML payload as content.

contents.title: gitlab
contents.description:
Objective: Being able to deploy a docus instance on gitlab pages
from a private repo and editing the whole thing trough nuxt studio.

children.value:
Objective: Being able to deploy a docus instance on gitlab pages
from a private repo and editing the whole thing trough nuxt studio.
have a public site while keeping the repo private
don't rely on nuxt studio for deployment (see 2023-11-03 cloudflare outage)
git commit/push to a private github repo
create personal access token or a fine-grained personal access token
create a synched gitlab repo, option
git commit/push to the private gitlab repo
static site should be deployed and running

contents.title: JSON schema
contents.description: See also JSON-schema (related to Nuxt studio):

children.value: we tell which extensions are involved.

It's fine to target single purpose file formats like '.xlsx' or '.csv'.
But it's not enough to set up a transformer for a special YAML or JSON based dialect.
We can use custom extension like
but it would be better to detect the thoses files without modifiyng them.
For JSON/YAML special dialects it is very common to use the

contents.title: Single Tree
contents.description: Let's have a single tree to organize all files related to content.

children.value: Let's have a single tree to organize all files related to content.
for files supported by nuxt content (md, json, yaml)
for files not content aware (jpeg, wbep, svg, ...)
some other folders of many file types related to other part of the platform (API, business logic design docs, file samples, ...)

We can't keep files together.
We have to put articles in
whereas images and exotic files must be in
We would like to set the Nuxt content source directly to

where we can easily tell which files are articles/images
or be ignored.

Maybe a set of rules telling how to traverse such a tree,
what to keep, what to ignore.
Those rules would be applied on each Nuxt generation.

contents.title: Feedback
contents.description: Here are some pitfalls and wishes from our Nuxt Studio experience.

children.value: Here are some pitfalls and wishes from our Nuxt Studio experience.

contents.title: escape key
contents.description: While editing a file, pressing the escape key move up one level on editor/browser hierarchy.

children.value: While editing a file, pressing the escape key move up one level on editor/browser hierarchy.

In the editor this beheviour is misleading if you use mutiple cursors.
The common way to exit multiple cursors is also pressing the escape key.
To be sure to exit the multiple cursors, I tend to press the escape key even if I'm not in multiple cursor, resulting in exiting the editor.
We may restrict the escape key behaviour to file browser and not in the editor.

contents.title: Easy fork
contents.description: On a single click, fork an existing github project and get :

children.value: On a single click, fork an existing github project and get :
a direct link from the README to nuxt studio
a running app via github pages
a new unique set of ID/API_KEY (generated on fork)
an auto-generated link to join the new nuxt studio team

contents.title: git
contents.description: We may use a simple git repo as Nuxt Studio source backend.

children.value: We may use a simple git repo as Nuxt Studio source backend.
Currently Nuxt Studio uses github as its source backend.
We will lose a lot of feature specific to github.
This will open a lot of new usecases where github is not an option :
edge hosting for speed (huge git repo)
special free tier feature (gitlab private repo with public pages, ...)

contents.title: JSON-schema
contents.description: Many features related to JSON-schema (some related to docus):

children.value:
while editing YAML file content.
It lets you validate your JSON or YAML content against a predefined
It's a life saver when you deal with strongly typed JSON/YAML content.
With a single first comment pointing to your schema, the editor will check if your content is valid :

props.code:
# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://paxpar.gitlab.io/schemas/checklist-2.0.schema.json
$schema: https://paxpar.gitlab.io/schemas/checklist-2.0.schema.json
name: Ordre d'intervention EDF
desc: Liste de vérification appliquée lors de la saisie d'un ordre d'intervention
tags:
  - atelier
owner:
  signature_pubkey: default

children.value: Liste de vérification appliquée lors de la saisie d'un ordre d'intervention

The schema URL could also be relative to the current project
where schemas would be stored in

props.code:
# yaml-language-server: $schema=/schemas/checklist-2.0.schema.json
$schema: https://paxpar.gitlab.io/schemas/checklist-2.0.schema.json
name: Ordre d'intervention EDF
desc: Liste de vérification appliquée lors de la saisie d'un ordre d'intervention
tags:
  - atelier
owner:
  signature_pubkey: default

children.value: Liste de vérification appliquée lors de la saisie d'un ordre d'intervention
will provide a kind of strong typing of document metadata.

props.code:
---
$schema: https://paxpar.tech/schema/mycheck/default/0
name: Ordre d'intervention EDF
desc: Liste de vérification appliquée lors de la saisie d'un ordre d'intervention
tags:
  - atelier
owner:
  signature_pubkey: default
---

# My document

Lorem ipsum ...

children.value: Liste de vérification appliquée lors de la saisie d'un ordre d'intervention

.
It lets you validate your JSON or YAML content against a predefined
Same feature as YAML file linter but restricted to the front-matter.

We may define visual component to edit typed YAML file.
The component will be registered to handle a given schema
and will produce the JSON/YAML payload.

contents.title: runtime use
contents.description: Use Nuxt Studio to edit live-content.

children.value: Use Nuxt Studio to edit live-content.
Think of a webapp where some pages fetch data from live sources (mostly YAML/JSON§/MD file in a S3 bucket).
Being able to edit those sources with Nuxt Studio without a full or partial site generation (when

contents.title: S3 bucket
contents.description: See also S3 bucket for docus.

children.value: We may use a S3 bucket as Nuxt Studio source backend.
Currently Nuxt Studio uses github as its source backend.
Editing files in Nuxt Studio will result in direct S3 file operations.
s3 is better than git for
git is better than s3 for
